I'm not big on zombie survival sims, but I'm not against them, and after seeing that you can actually take a camper for a mobile base in this game, I've decided to give it a try.

The good:
1) Drivable vehicles. I don't know why they've all been stripped of parts, though. It's probably a balance thing. A bit annyoing having to hunt for so many parts, then to carry them back to the vehicle you want, but whatever, at least it give you purpose.
2) You can have a camper for a mobile base! Yes, as I've said, it was the main selling point for me. Now the camper's a bit small, but I've managed to cram a double-bed, several containers and a large shelf inside it, so I'm quite happy. Still, would be nice to have RVs as well.
3) You can use paint to recolour your vehicle and camper. Finally, I can live my hippie camper dream!
4) Large map to explore. I've not explored for long, but from what I've gathered there are supposed to be several zones, so having a vehicle is indeed important.
5) Storage, storage everywhere. Portable storage, vehicle storage, a cart that you can drag around to carry all that storage. It's useful, and it helps to not need to build your own containers, like so many survival sims make you do.
6) I actually like the fact that you can pick up random props and take them with you. Lets you make your base your own, and the prop placement mechanic is pretty good (my only qualm is that I sometimes pick stuff up instead of "using" it, but this can be fixed by changing the key bindings, I think).
7) Wild, non-zombified animals. I don't actually know of any zombie survival sims that feature non-zombified animals. Here, though, I've come across two bears, just chilling around. The game is supposed to have other animals also, but I've not met any so far.
8) You can modify your guns. You've got suppressors, sights, grips, stocks, whatever. And the gun-mods actually help, the supressor prevents enemies from getting alerted, for example.
9) The game has a day\ night cycle, changing weather, and apparently seasons. Haven't reached winter yet, and I could really use some rain, but whatever, it's still good.
10) The game can be pretty.

The bad:
1) The zombie AI is pretty dumb. The zombies run at you mindlessly, but if you climb on something, or close a door in front of them, they just stand there, helplessly flailing their arms at you. Yet they also have enough intelligence to run for cover when in direct sunlight? That's just weird.
2) Grammar. Way I understand it, English is not the developer('s') native language, so technically this can be forgiven, especially since you can indeed understand what the game is telling you, but it just irks me when I see some of the weird grammar. Get a proof-reader, please!
3) The crafting is actually pretty complex, which is pretty good. But most of it requires a workbench, which sucks.
4) Some resources are way too abundant, but you have little use for them until you have access to a workbench, so they just take up space in your storage. I've gathered up so many rags, so much scrap metal, and so many 'components', yet I can't do anything to them! (again, not until I get to a workbench).
5) Quivers. You can find bows and arrows in the world, but can't use them, because you didn't find a quiver. As an amateur archer in real life, and a fan of achery in video-games, I find this design choice really frustrating.
6) Using some of the items is just busywork. So there are two ways you can carry an item: in your inventory (not all items) or in your hands (most items). The problem is that if you want to actually use some of the items, you need first hold them in your hands, because, for whatever reason, the game doesn't acknowledge you having them if they're in your inventory. I understand that it's a realism thing, but using an item straight out of your inventory is just a far better design choice.
7) Daytime is way too short. At 6 PM it's already pitch black outside, meaning that you have to go to sleep for 12 whole hours, unless you want to run around fighting or dodging zombies. The game supposedly features seasons, but there doesn't seem to be a difference in daylight between summer and winter.

The ugly:
1) The game is badly optimized, even if your computer can run it on highest settings, you still need to wait for all the assets to render before you can actually start playing, and even then you might have to deal with props just popping into view as you go. I've seen a playthrough where the player was driving his car pretty fast and crashed into a broken bus that wasn't there just a moment ago, because the game didn't manage to render it in. Was a bit funny, but it's actually a serious problem.

Suggestions:
Aside from what I've written above, I'd like the option to switch off zombies\ bandits\ hostile animals when starting a new game. Sometimes you just want to explore the game world, to see how long you can survive without some mob constantly knocking down your door. Green Hell lets you do this, The Long Dark lets you do this, so why not? I get that the game's whole plot revolves around zombies, but options are always a good thing. Project Zomboid lets you toggle zombies off at new game, so why not? 
Another suggestion is to let us wield weapons lefthanded. I know it's extra work for the devs, but since you're already giving us the option to use the left hand for secondary items, why not make it fully useable?

Overall, I like this game. If the devs fix its standing issues, it might just become a genre staple.

I love this game. I'm currently 65 hours into it and still having a blast. There are some bugs that you will come across but that's to be expected with an early access game. Let me dive right in and give some thoughts and helpful tips for new players or those thinking of buying the game.
1. When you first spawn in, look around and loot all you can. Be sure to grab the backpack nearby too and check the little wooden container. You don't want to stay here. There is absolutely 0 protection from anything. Your best bet is to find a cabin or some sort or a white house and start setting up shop even if it's just temporary.
2. Daytime starts at 5 am (the birds will start singing) and nighttime starts at around 19:30ish, although I've never encountered a zombie before 22:00... yet.
3. Mist encounters last anywhere from 1 to 4 hours. You can hide up in water towers (zombies can't climb... yet), inside cabins that have no boarded up windows (zombies can break through boarded up windows and come inside to kill you - if the window isn't boarded up, then zombies can't enter through it), inside drivable vehicles if you've restored them, on top of the taller army vehicles, some of the motel rooms are zombie free and safe to hide in, the ranger towers are great, upstairs in the white houses there are bedrooms with doors you can shut and be safe. There are other places, but those are just a few that are easy to come across.
4. Hitting TAB brings up some basic stats as well as the time.
5. Read the dang tutorial. It's got some helpful beginning information about your stats and such.
6. I try to carry at least 1 food, 1 water, 1 bandage and a way to defend myself at all times.
7. Don't eat uncooked food or drink unsafe water. It tells you if food is raw or not and it says safe/unsafe on water. Colas are common and always safe. Potatoes NEED to be cooked. The other veggies can be eaten without cooking.
8. The livestock fencing keeps the zombies out. You can place then build them over the boarded up windows and make your building safe to live in. Zombies don't break them at all. I like to live in the white houses, use the livestock fencing to block all the boarded up windows and build a big area out front that holds my blacksmith and other items. Also gives me a place to stab the zombies in the face with a spear without getting hit if I want that extra loot! The zombies will gather at whatever livestock gates you've put along your livestock fence and you can safely stab them and collect loot after the mist or night has ended.
9. The biggest tip I can give you is to save often. Get a good loot run? Save. Kill a bear? Save. Save. Save. If you die, you have 2 options, respawn and chance a bunch of your stuff being gone or quit to menu and resume from your last save point. If you save often it's never a big loss to quit to menu and come back into the game.
10. Temperature is currently irrelevant as of right now. There is no winter. There is no pants or jacket in game yet.
11. There is no map in game (yet?), but you can easily google search for one. 
12. Suitcases, lockers, and some of the small wooden crates can be storage containers. You can pick them up with M and move them to your base.
13. You can search the cars that don't have tinted windows. Don't forget to check under the hood for gas (if you've got a jerrycan) or spare car parts. There is usually goodies in the trunk and sometimes inside the cars themselves. The vehicles with tinted windows you can destroy with an axe or sledgehammer for metal scraps, components, wood, car parts, etc...
14. If your fatigue bar reaches 0, your stamina will NOT regenerate. The only way to fix that is to rest or sleep. Sometimes eating/drinking helps if your fatigue/stamina is low since it forces you to rest a bit. So make sure you're sleeping regularly to keep that fatigue bar in good condition.
15. If you rescue one of the AI's, you can give them a gun. They will help defend your base.
16. Absolutely under no circumstances log out of the game or save inside of a mine. You will fall through the world and die with no way out except to respawn and lose a bunch of stuff in the process.
17. Be on the lookout for backpacks to increase your inventory size. They are spread out everywhere. Bandit camps usually have 1, ranger towers, starting locations, etc. Just walk up and hit F on them to expand your inventory.
18. Once you repair a vehicle, try to keep some spare parts and gas in the trunk or in a storage container if you've got a truck. If something goes wrong,  you will want to have them handy to fix your vehicle so you can get home easily. 
19. You can put storage containers in the bed of the trucks you fix up. Lockers, suitcases, small wooden crates, or you can simply stand on the tailgate and yeet items into the back from your inventory. You can put items like the sawbench, workbench, water containers etc back there too. 
20. When you're searching for loot, be sure to check nightstands, dressers, cupboards, wardrobes, anything with drawers. There is hidden goodies in there sometimes.
21. Be careful with heights. It doesn't take much to get a sprained ankle at which point you will be stuck walking until it heals 30+ in game minutes (and that's if you're lucky and have painkillers). If you're out in the world that makes you an easy target for zombies, bandits and bears since you can't run away.
22. If you're having a hard time finding items on the ground like sticks, rocks, feathers, leaves.. you can turn down the foliage in the settings. Sorta cheaty but who am I to judge, I'm blind as a bat and use this trick myself hehe.
I really hope they add a co-op or multiplayer function to this game. It would absolutely make it 100% better to be able to play with friends. Also the ability to mod it would be fantastic too!
Remember, save often and have fun!
This review has been posted on 5/10/2021 and the game is subject to change which can make some of these tips useless in later releases.

As a big fan of Dying Light and desperately waiting for the sequel, I wanted to try Mist Survival and I have to admit that it’s a very addictive game! Gameplay is great, every step needs to be planned. At the start, it feels like danger is everywhere, but after almost 20h of gameplay, I’m settled in and feel much more confident. 

As many of us, I took the white house as my base, 2 floors with a bed and some cabinets. 
The first days I got ambushed several times during the night by the undead, but after placing a chicken fence IN every window (trick I found on the net), no zombie gets in and I feel much more secure, also after placing some of those fences before my front door. I can jump over, zombies can’t. What bandits concerns, I never saw one yet (edit: while writing this, I cleaned out my first bandit camp). But again, I’m the type who likes to feel completely safe and well equipped before going out on long trips or engaging enemy’s.  

Food and water
...are vital for surviving. First, roaming the immediate vicinity of your base should be enough to find water, coke cans, canned food and all types of supplies you need to build things. You can find them in abandoned cars and buildings. Some buildings contain zombies (you hear them when approaching), so better leave these alone, for now. 
When you decide to expand your range, you can take one of the many cars randomly available, but you need to get them to work first by finding spare parts. But that shouldn’t take much time as there are many available. Fuel can be unloaded, but you need a jerry can to do so. I had found one in a small cabin close to the farm (large fields). But you can also make one (see later). Be aware that these car parts wear out rather quickly (especially when you hit a bear, another car…), so better stock on spare parts, and (hint) put them in the trunk of your car so you have them with you when your car stops driving in the middle of nowhere when the mist comes up :s 

What to build first. 
In the meantime, the searching through cars and buildings will have given you probably a saw, axe and hammer. So you can start building! 

First I fortified my villa to feel more safe, especially at night. Building a chicken fence is easy and doesn’t need many materials. (hint) if you want several of these fences interlocking, place them first without effectively building them. 

Secondly, I built a ‘Barrel fire’, not to use as a fire place, but to make wooden planks out of tree trunks that you need to build e.g. the ‘Workbench’. The ‘Workbench’ is a must-have tool. Then I started building a ‘water purifier’ and ‘water barrel’ to solve the thirst issue. You need to find water to put in the purifier. The villa happens to be close to a lake. You need an empty bottle or better a bucket (10l) to transport the ‘unsafe’ water back to your base. I had found a bucket while searching the area, but you can make one yourself with scrap metal you find using the Workbench.    

Weapons
During my travels around my villa, progressively going further and further, I spotted 2 ‘Guard towers’ and yes they gave me a pistol and shotgun! Ammo is scarce I have to admit, I have around a dozen cartridges for each weapon at this time. Ammo can also be found in the white villa’s you come across. In one of these villa’s, I found an M4 rifle. 
Making a bow (go for the longbow, the first is a waste of time and supplies) is time consuming. You need ‘dried animal guts’.
Drying? So you need to construct a ‘Drying rack’.
No bow without quiver. For a quiver, you need leather, for making leather you need dry animal hide...so you need to build a ‘Tanning rack’. Keeping busy. 
By the time I decided to make a bow, I had found several arrows during my trips outside. Hunting arrows are a must. You can also make them with wood branches, feathers and arrowheads that you can produce with the ‘Blacksmith place’.

Where to find animal guts and hide? Bears maybe.
And while doing all this time consuming constructions, you need food so you need to constantly search the area to find food cans. After a while, you like to find a better source of food. Bears maybe? 

Bears.
There happens to be one roaming the area of my base. Thought to give it a try. One shotgun blast to the head killed the animal. I could extract raw meat, guts, fat & hide. (hint) adjust the amount you want to remove as it’s standard “0” so it won’t do anything. 
Taking all that to your base.
You can place the hide to the ‘Tanning rack’ to dry (takes lots of time!).
Before you can use the animal guts for the bow or eat the meat, you must dry it on the ‘Drying rack’. Before you can put the meat on the drying rack, you need to add ‘salt’ to it. Salt can be found on zombies and obviously in kitchens of some buildings you come across. Keeping busy. But a piece of dried bear meat can feed you for a much longer time than a beef can. So you can keep the canned food for the periods in between the bear killings and drying times. 
Eating raw meat (or unsafe water) can give you food poisoning, which again can be helped with antibiotics you may have found. For 2 or 3 times, I had a food poisoning without eating any of that (don’t know if it’s a bug?).

Mist events. 
These occur randomly as far as I know. Once coming up, zombies starts to appear. Initially I quickly ran back to my base. I still try to run or drive to my base if possible, but when too far away, I quickly hide in my car and that seems to keep you safe. Once I thought I would drive back to my base in the mist, but not seeing much I got lost and still had to wait in my car. 
When I’m at my base and mist comes up, I try to attract some zombies and while hiding behind my chicken fence wall in front of my door, I try to kill them with the bow. They drop salt, gunpowder...and you can retrieve the arrows, which is a good thing.

What else did I build?
A ‘Blacksmith place’. I did make some ingots of scrap metal, I needed nails and had to build a pickaxe needed in the mines. I made two visits to the mines where I extracted some iron, zinc, copper, sulphur etc (again, you need a pickaxe!). You need a lot of copper ores to make brass ingots which you can use to make cartridge cases. With sulphur and saltpetre you make the gun powder. 
To effectively combine both to make ammo, you need to build a ‘Reloading bench’.
Why there is gold in the mine, I don’t know, maybe something we can use after further updating the game. 

I also placed a ‘Chicken coop’, chickens are roaming close to my base. You need to run empty handed and when close use the ‘F’ button to grab them; release them (‘R’) in your ‘Chicken coop’. They do produce eggs, which you can eat but this adds barely something to your food bar. I let the eggs alone, I thought maybe they do hatch? But that didn’t happen, instead they were rotting so I had to throw them away. You can also kill chickens, pick them up and ‘harvest’ them for some meat and feathers.

‘Lock picks’. Easy to craft. Take some with you during your travels as behind these closed doors interesting things can be found: weapons, ammo, ‘backpack upgrades’ (to increase your inventory slots). An alternative is making a ‘crowbar’.  
You may find cloths that you can put on, does this mean you were naked all the time before? 

I admit I’m a hoarder so I have built 7 extra ‘Security Lockers’ to store and organise all my items.
I had my first interaction with bandits, but there was sort of bug as 2 of them came very close and kept walking against me, without attacking me. The game is in alpha stage and I’m almost 20h far in the game, so I still have things to do, but I wanted to write some ‘tips & tricks’ that may be useful to new players.
